docs.lead_paragraph: Fishing boats used high-tech systems to find vast schools of fish for decades, depleting stocks of some species and leading to the complete collapse of others. Now more than a dozen apps, devices and monitoring systems aimed at tracking unscrupulous vessels and the seafood they catch are being rolled out — high-tech solutions some say could also help prevent labor abuse at sea.

docs.lead_paragraph: I HAVE used the Macintosh operating system for more than a decade, and Windows off and on since it became less annoying a few years ago, but the notion of trying Linux intrigued me. Could someone like me, without a computer science degree or past love affairs with a Radio Shack TRS-80, do anything with Linux -- like installing it on an old PC and getting it to do things I usually do on my I.B.M. ThinkPad or Mac G4 desktop-tower machine? Linux, the free, sturdy operating system created 10 years ago by Linus Torvalds of Finland, has been getting more and more attention in the last couple of years because it has a populist cachet and runs well on inexpensive hardware; Version 2.4 of the Linux kernel (the brains of the system) was released in January. It has made inroads in the server market, but it is also starting to show up installed on personal computers from major computer makers like I.B.M. and Dell as an alternative to Windows.
docs.abstract: J D Biersdorfer State of the Art column recounts his experiences while testing Linux, only competitor to Microsoft's Windows and Apple's OS in field of computer operating systems; created ten years ago by Linus Torvalds, Linux' popularity is growing; it is being installed by some yanufacturers in new personal computers, despite challenges it poses to users unfamiliar with its language and processes; author suggests that adventurous individuals install Linux in old computers and explore its possibilities (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TO design the perfect solar house, Heather Korb and her fellow architecture students at the New York Institute of Technology wanted to do more than just harness the sun with solar panels. ''Our philosophy is to live in harmony with the earth as part of one sustainable ecology,'' said Ms. Korb, 26, of St. James, a fourth-year student at the institute's Old Westbury campus.

headline.main: 800 Square Feet and Zero Energy Bills

docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMER on the boardwalk at Seaside Heights: Ecstatic squeals pierce the night as riders are spun, hurled and whisked aloft on amusement rides along Casino Pier. Fried onions perfume the air. Hordes of revelers parade the planks while a mishmash of signs tempt their craws. CORN! STEAK! BEER! scream the signs. CLAMS! DOGS! FRIES! But really, only one food truly says summer. And sooner or later, like ships to the beacon, like moths to the flame, customers succumb to the call of ice cream. But not just any ice cream. This is Seaside Heights, after all, where the cool lick of choice is Kohr's frozen custard.
docs.abstract: Article tries to untangle truth and fiction about history of Khor's frozen custard, a staple of summertime along Casino Pier in Seaside Heights, NJ and other locations along Jersey Shore; Original Kohr's and Kohr's Frozen Custard Inc are based in Seaside Heights and third company, Kohr Brothers, is based in Charlottesville, Va; photos; map (M)

headline.main: There's a Triple Dip Of These Descendants Making Frozen Custard

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Anne Foerst, 34, a researcher at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the director of M.I.T.'s God and Computers project, apologized on a recent afternoon that a certain robot named Kismet wouldn't be joining our interview. ''Cynthia Breazeal, who built Kismet, is away in Japan right now and there's no getting her going,'' Dr. Foerst said in her German accent, ''but you'd love her. She's oh so cute.'' A cute robot? Well, yes. At the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, engineers are trying to build robots with social skills and humanlike experiences, and so, as an experiment, they've created creatures that they think humans will relate to.
docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Anne Foerst, researcher at Artificial Ingelligence Laboratory at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and director of MIT's God and Computers project; Foerst, a Lutheran minister, says laboratory is trying to build robots that are social and embodied; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In George Foreman's first boxing incarnation, he was a lean, snarling ogre who mauled Joe Frazier to win the heavyweight championship 27 years ago. When he returned in 1987 after a 10-year retirement preaching on streets and eating his way to 310 pounds, Foreman II became an image of mirth with punch speed measured by an egg timer.
docs.abstract: Article on former heavyweight boxing champion George Foreman's success as a marketer; says what is unique about Forman's ability to package himself is his sale of his name, as opposed to being paid to endorse products; focuses on success of his nonstick grill that manufacturer Salton bought rights to and use of Foreman's name, paying Foreman $137.5 million; Foreman comments; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT the driver station behind a glass partition, Steven Ellinghaus and Randy Earle maneuvered their joysticks. On the playing field in front of the Farmingdale High School students, SCAG -- an acronym for Second Chance at Glory -- a robot that looked like an upright vacuum cleaner zipped across the carpet only to get stuck midfield by the dividing rail. Steven and Randy veered SCAG to the right, then the left, unable to move him to the other side. Suddenly, EInstein, a low-slung robot built by the Red Jammers, East Islip High School's robotics team, charged right across the seesawing midfield ramp. As Bryan Prosek worked its remote controls, EInstein grabbed a large neon ball and placed it on a seven-foot goal. Then the robot pushed the goal onto the pivoting bridge, balancing it. Pulsating music and the play-by-play blared. Colored lights flashed. Robots from Longwood and Hampton Bays high schools hovered in the end zones. Umpires watched the mechanical gladiators, scrutinizing each movement. And in the stands, 3,000 fans cheered wildly as the buzzer signaling the end of the two-minute round went off.
docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column: Third annual Long Island First Robotics Competition draws 34 high school teams to regional competition at Suffolk County Community College; sixth annual Long Island Executives Corporate Monopoly Challenge is held at Heckscher Museum; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 1968 film ''The Producers,'' Zero Mostel played Max Bialystock, a crooked Broadway producer. When he's not bilking widows out of their fortunes, Max turns his attention to hiring Ulla (played by Lee Meredith), a secretary with no apparent understanding of English. When asked to perform stenography or any other work, Ulla responds by go-go dancing. The Ullas of the early 21st century -- digital voice recorders -- can't dance. And even though these digital stenographers occasionally seem to share Ulla's limited grasp of English, they have reached a point where they are now a viable alternative for getting words into computer without using a keyboard.
docs.abstract: Digital voice recorders have become viable alternative for getting words onto paper without using keyboards; article assesses current digital dictation devices; photo (M)
